description.safe_value: The CDT Project provides a fully functional C and C++ Integrated Development Environment based on the Eclipse platform. Features include: support for project creation and managed build for various toolchains, standard make build, source navigation, various source knowledge tools, such as type hierarchy, call graph, include browser, macro definition browser, code editor with syntax highlighting, folding and hyperlink navigation, source code refactoring and code generation, visual debugging tools, including memory, registers, and disassembly viewers.
description.value: The CDT Project provides a fully functional C and C++ Integrated Development Environment based on the Eclipse platform. Features include: support for project creation and managed build for various toolchains, standard make build, source navigation, various source knowledge tools, such as type hierarchy, call graph, include browser, macro definition browser, code editor with syntax highlighting, folding and hyperlink navigation, source code refactoring and code generation, visual debugging tools, including memory, registers, and disassembly viewers.

deliverables.value:
CDT 8.8 focuses on bug fixes and new features such as:
  • Parser
    • User-defined literals
  • Debug
    • C/C++ Stand-alone Debugger package (RCP) for Windows
    • Create breakpoint from breakpoints view menu
    • DSF-GDB service extensibility improvement
    • The "Find Replace" context menu option is now available from the Memory view and Memory Browser view
    • The "Add Watchpoint (C/C++)" context menu option is now available from the Memory Browser view

CDT 8.8 focuses on bug fixes and new features such as:
  • Parser
    • User-defined literals
  • Debug

    • Create breakpoint from breakpoints view menu
    • DSF-GDB service extensibility improvement
    • The "Find Replace" context menu option is now available from the Memory view and Memory Browser view
    • The "Add Watchpoint (C/C++)" context menu option is now available from the Memory Browser view

security.value: There are no security issues.
security.safe_value: There are no security issues.

usability.value: Some new context-menu actions have been added to provide users easier access to certain debugger feature.
usability.safe_value: Some new context-menu actions have been added to provide users easier access to certain debugger feature.

endoflife.value: We have officially announced on the mailing list that the CDI debugger framework will be removed from the CDT code base in the next CDT release.  No steps in that direction will be taken in this 8.8 release.  This will reduce code complexity and confusion to newcomers.  CDI has not be worked on for years and has been replaced by the DSF framework.
endoflife.safe_value: We have officially announced on the mailing list that the CDI debugger framework will be removed from the CDT code base in the next CDT release.  No steps in that direction will be taken in this 8.8 release.  This will reduce code complexity and confusion to newcomers.  CDI has not be worked on for years and has been replaced by the DSF framework.

standards.value: No changes for this release.
standards.safe_value: No changes for this release.

description.safe_value: CDT 8.8.0 is a minor release that ships with the Mars.1 update release.  It fixes bugs and brings new features which are listed in the corresponding CDT New&Noteworthy page.
description.value: CDT 8.8.0 is a minor release that ships with the Mars.1 update release.  It fixes bugs and brings new features which are listed in the corresponding CDT New&Noteworthy page.

environment.safe_value: As a direct answer to requests from our user forum, CDT 8.8 includes a Windows version of the C/C++ RCP Stand-alone debugger.
environment.value: As a direct answer to requests from our user forum, CDT 8.8 includes a Windows version of the C/C++ RCP Stand-alone debugger.

communities.safe_value:
Development activities continue for CDT and are quite varied.  The debug component, the parser, the build system, the static analyser (codan), the support for remote, and other components are getting some attention from committers and contributors.

We see interactions on the mailing list from adopters and get continued confirmation that CDT is being extended by many companies.

The user community interacts with the project through the forum at a very manageable pace.

We have seen some consultants getting involved in CDT to address their customer's issues.  We hope to see this continue and to grow the number of our committers.
communities.value:
Development activities continue for CDT and are quite varied.  The debug component, the parser, the build system, the static analyser (codan), the support for remote, and other components are getting some attention from committers and contributors.

We see interactions on the mailing list from adopters and get continued confirmation that CDT is being extended by many companies.

The user community interacts with the project through the forum at a very manageable pace.

We have seen some consultants getting involved in CDT to address their customer's issues.  We hope to see this continue and to grow the number of our committers.

noncode.value: Documentation is barely being maintained.  The project relies on internet searches and questions on the forum or mailing list to address user issues.
noncode.safe_value: Documentation is barely being maintained.  The project relies on internet searches and questions on the forum or mailing list to address user issues.

compatibility.safe_value: As the previous release, CDT 8.8 still requires Java 7 and Elcipse 4.5
compatibility.value: As the previous release, CDT 8.8 still requires Java 7 and Elcipse 4.5

communities.safe_value:
The CDT can be setup using Oomph.  We hope this lowers the barrier-to-entry and stimulates the growth of our community.

CDT has also begun a focus on supporting open source toolchains for hobbyist computer engineers using accessible hardware platforms such as Arduino, Raspberry Pi, and the ESP8266 amongst others. If we can make the CDT useful and loved by this community, then we'll be successful satisfying the pros, especially as the hobbyists take their talents to the next level and be come those pros. With this release, we introduce a preview of the feature supporting Arduino.
communities.value:
The CDT can be setup using Oomph.  We hope this lowers the barrier-to-entry and stimulates the growth of our community.

CDT has also begun a focus on supporting open source toolchains for hobbyist computer engineers using accessible hardware platforms such as Arduino, Raspberry Pi, and the ESP8266 amongst others. If we can make the CDT useful and loved by this community, then we'll be successful satisfying the pros, especially as the hobbyists take their talents to the next level and be come those pros. With this release, we introduce a preview of the feature supporting Arduino.

noncode.safe_value: With this release CDT now provides support for development on Arduino.
noncode.value: With this release CDT now provides support for development on Arduino.

deliverables.safe_value:
CDT 8.7 focuses on bug fixes and the following new features:
  • General
    • Project-less Execution
    • Process exit code shown in execution console title
    • Launching an application in a Docker container (both Run and Debug modes)
  • Editor
    • Options for Format with Empty Selection
  • Debug
    • Debugging an application by launching it in a Docker container
    • RCP Standalone Debugger
    • Exited processes shown in the debug view
    • Multicore Visualizer
      • Add persistent information storage
      • Make showing debug actions in toolbar configurable
    • Simplified extensibility for CDT's debug views
deliverables.value:
CDT 8.7 focuses on bug fixes and the following new features:
  • General
    • Project-less Execution
    • Process exit code shown in execution console title
    • Launching an application in a Docker container (both Run and Debug modes)
  • Editor
    • Options for Format with Empty Selection
  • Debug
    • Debugging an application by launching it in a Docker container
    • RCP Standalone Debugger
    • Exited processes shown in the debug view
    • Multicore Visualizer
      • Add persistent information storage
      • Make showing debug actions in toolbar configurable
    • Simplified extensibility for CDT's debug views

security.value: There are no security issues.
security.safe_value: There are no security issues.

usability.safe_value:
The new Launch Bar will be released along with this CDT release.  It aims at simplifying the launching of applicaitons in the different supported modes, such as Run and Debug.  It is provided as an optional feature to users.

Although part of the CDT project, the Launch Bar does not depend on CDT and can be installed without it to be used with other languages.
usability.value:
The new Launch Bar will be released along with this CDT release.  It aims at simplifying the launching of applicaitons in the different supported modes, such as Run and Debug.  It is provided as an optional feature to users.

Although part of the CDT project, the Launch Bar does not depend on CDT and can be installed without it to be used with other languages.

endoflife.value: The ancient CDI debug interface is sometimes causing confusion to new comers who don't realize that code is end-of-life. Nothing will be done for this release as it is a maintenance release. However, the plan is to do a major release for the Neon release, which would include the removal of the CDI code.

Nothing will be done for this release as it is a maintenance release. However, the plan is to do a major release for the Neon release, which would include the removal of the CDI code.

standards.value: No changes for this release.
standards.safe_value: No changes for this release.

description.value: CDT 8.7.0 is a minor release that ships with the Mars simultaneous release.  It fixes bugs and brings new features which are listed in the corresponding CDT New&Noteworthy page.
description.safe_value: CDT 8.7.0 is a minor release that ships with the Mars simultaneous release.  It fixes bugs and brings new features which are listed in the corresponding CDT New&Noteworthy page.

architecture.safe_value:
With this release, the CDT now depends on org.eclipse.remote.  The dependency to RSE has not be removed however, and the remote debugging feature of CDT still uses RSE.  We have plans to migrate this feature to use org.eclipse.remote, but time did not allow us to complete this for this release.

Furthermore, we currently have a circular dependency issue where CDT depends on org.eclipse.remote, but org.eclipse.remote depends on the CDT's org.eclipse.cdt.native plugins.  The plan is to break out the org.eclipse.cdt.native plugins into their own build so as to allow org.eclipse.remote to be built before the rest of CDT is built.

Added support for serial port to the native plug-ins. The medium term plan once Mars is over is to package and re-license that plugin EDL to enable it for more general use by the Java community as a replacement and more license friendly alternative to libraries such as RXTX.
architecture.value:
With this release, the CDT now depends on org.eclipse.remote.  The dependency to RSE has not be removed however, and the remote debugging feature of CDT still uses RSE.  We have plans to migrate this feature to use org.eclipse.remote, but time did not allow us to complete this for this release.

Furthermore, we currently have a circular dependency issue where CDT depends on org.eclipse.remote, but org.eclipse.remote depends on the CDT's org.eclipse.cdt.native plugins.  The plan is to break out the org.eclipse.cdt.native plugins into their own build so as to allow org.eclipse.remote to be built before the rest of CDT is built.

Added support for serial port to the native plug-ins. The medium term plan once Mars is over is to package and re-license that plugin EDL to enable it for more general use by the Java community as a replacement and more license friendly alternative to libraries such as RXTX.

environment.value: CDT can now run on PowerPC Little Endian (ppc64le) architectures.
environment.safe_value: CDT can now run on PowerPC Little Endian (ppc64le) architectures.

compatibility.value: This release is compatible with previous releases.
compatibility.safe_value: This release is compatible with previous releases.

noncode.safe_value:
As of this release, we are reducing the number of GDB versions we officially support.  We now only provide support for GDBs that are more recent or equal to versions 7.1 which is already 5 years old.  The CDT should continue to work with older versions, but committers will not verify this anymore.

CDT now provides an example plugin that shows how to extend its debugger.
noncode.value:
As of this release, we are reducing the number of GDB versions we officially support.  We now only provide support for GDBs that are more recent or equal to versions 7.1 which is already 5 years old.  The CDT should continue to work with older versions, but committers will not verify this anymore.

CDT now provides an example plugin that shows how to extend its debugger.

communities.value: The CDT is going full-speed in its use of Gerrit and contributions are coming in steadily.  We try to make the contribution process as easy and smooth as possible. The number of committers remains stable but we would like to see it grow further.
communities.safe_value: The CDT is going full-speed in its use of Gerrit and contributions are coming in steadily.  We try to make the contribution process as easy and smooth as possible. The number of committers remains stable but we would like to see it grow further.

endoflife.value: The ancient CDI debug interface is sometimes causing confusion to new comers who don't realize that code is end-of-life. Nothing will be done for this relase as it is a maintenance release. Consideration will be made to improve the situation for the Mars release.  The question of doing a major release has been brought to the communities attention and would open the door to doing a major cleanup of such code.
endoflife.safe_value: The ancient CDI debug interface is sometimes causing confusion to new comers who don't realize that code is end-of-life. Nothing will be done for this relase as it is a maintenance release. Consideration will be made to improve the situation for the Mars release.  The question of doing a major release has been brought to the communities attention and would open the door to doing a major cleanup of such code.

usability.safe_value:
The CDT continues to follow Eclipse User Interface Guidelines however efforts to improve usability of Launch Configurations continue.  For this release, there are no major changes included, but in the next release we expect to release the new Launch Bar.

We have a continuing issue in making users aware of new features.  Different suggestions have been proposed but nothing has been done yet.

architecture.value: The CDT currently depends on RSE to support remote debugging.  This will continue to be true for this release but we plan on moving to org.eclipse.remote for the next release.

description.safe_value: CDT 8.6.0 is a minor release that ships with the Luna Service Release 2.  It fixes bugs and brings new features which are listed in the corresponding CDT New&Noteworthy page.
description.value: CDT 8.6.0 is a minor release that ships with the Luna Service Release 2.  It fixes bugs and brings new features which are listed in the corresponding CDT New&Noteworthy page.

deliverables.value:
For the 8.6.0 release, the CDT project will focus on the following feature requests as well as bug fixes. 

New features are:

  • Editor
    • Save actions
  • Refactoring
    • File rename when renaming a class
  • Debug
    • Display of GDB version
    • Display of thread names
    • Per-element number format
    • Terminating or disconnecting multiple processes with one command
    • Register grouping
    • Pinning of Multicore Visualizer view
    • Edit connection properties in remote launch
    • Remote debugging support in the Standalone Debugger
    • Example plug-in extending DSF-GDB
  • Miscellaneous
    • PowerPC little endian support
deliverables.safe_value:
For the 8.6.0 release, the CDT project will focus on the following feature requests as well as bug fixes. 

New features are:

  • Editor
    • Save actions
  • Refactoring
    • File rename when renaming a class
  • Debug
    • Display of GDB version
    • Display of thread names
    • Per-element number format
    • Terminating or disconnecting multiple processes with one command
    • Register grouping
    • Pinning of Multicore Visualizer view
    • Edit connection properties in remote launch
    • Remote debugging support in the Standalone Debugger
    • Example plug-in extending DSF-GDB
  • Miscellaneous
    • PowerPC little endian support

security.safe_value: There are no security issues.
security.value: There are no security issues.

endoflife.value: The ancient CDI debug interface remains end-of-lifed. Consideration will be made to remove it in the Mars (2015) timeframe. Interfaces should be deprecated in the code first.
endoflife.safe_value: The ancient CDI debug interface remains end-of-lifed. Consideration will be made to remove it in the Mars (2015) timeframe. Interfaces should be deprecated in the code first.

usability.value: The CDT continues to follow Eclipse User Interface Guidelines however there have been discussions on different fronts about how to improve the user experience.  For this release, there are no major changes, but in future releases, the CDT will simplify and modernize usability, especially in the area of Launch Configurations.
usability.safe_value: The CDT continues to follow Eclipse User Interface Guidelines however there have been discussions on different fronts about how to improve the user experience.  For this release, there are no major changes, but in future releases, the CDT will simplify and modernize usability, especially in the area of Launch Configurations.

architecture.safe_value: There are no new or noteworthy architectural issues with this release.  The CDT committers continue to strive to make the project easy to extend.
architecture.value: There are no new or noteworthy architectural issues with this release.  The CDT committers continue to strive to make the project easy to extend.

standards.safe_value:
The CDT supports the C++11 standard almost fully and provides some support for the C++14 standard.  No extended support was added in this release.

On the Debugging side, lldb has recently added an MI interface which allows to integrate it with the CDT.  We plan on looking further into this to help provide better support in future releases.

description.safe_value: CDT 8.5.0 is a minor release that ships with the Luna Service Release 1.  It brings new features as described in the CDT New&Noteworthy page.
description.value: CDT 8.5.0 is a minor release that ships with the Luna Service Release 1.  It brings new features as described in the CDT New&Noteworthy page.

deliverables.safe_value:
For the 8.5.0 release, the CDT project will focus on the most pressing feature requests as well as bug fixes. 

New features are:

  •     Editor
    •     Filtering Read-Only References in Search View
    •     Include Guard Style
    •     Completion of Template Arguments
    •     Default Arguments in Content Assist
  •     Indexing
    •     Labels as Values
  •     Refactoring
    •     Header File Rename
  •     Debug
    •     Cloning of Visualizer view

noncode.safe_value:
There have been minor updates to user and API documentation. Little else has been done to support learning the CDT.

Internationalization continue to be a priority for CDT. All strings have been externalized.

There have been minor updates to user and API documentation. Little else has been done to support learning the CDT.

Internationalization continue to be a priority for CDT. All strings have been externalized.

communities.value:
CDT community remains strong with 100 open change requests in Gerrit and a continuing flow of bug reports. The number of active committers though is fairly low. Work will need to be done to grow that again.

Marc Khouzam has been elected as co-lead to help Doug Schaefer with the community and manage release. Marc has done a great job of leading the debug components of CDT and his promotion here recognise the great work he's already doing.

usability.value:
The multicore visualizer continues to gain usability improvements and is our major usability feature to support complex workflows with multicore debugging.

Look for more focus on usablity of creating new projects and managing launch configurations towards 8.5.

description.safe_value: CDT 8.4 is a minor release that ships with the Luna simultaneous release.
description.value: CDT 8.4 is a minor release that ships with the Luna simultaneous release.

standards.safe_value:
CDT marches forward with support of the C++11 standard almost full. Work has started on C++14 support.

GCC remains our standard for toolchain support both compiler and debug. Most toolchains in the industry strive to be compatible anyway, including clang and upcoming with lldb.
standards.value:
CDT marches forward with support of the C++11 standard almost full. Work has started on C++14 support.

GCC remains our standard for toolchain support both compiler and debug. Most toolchains in the industry strive to be compatible anyway, including clang and upcoming with lldb.

architecture.value:
Continuing reports of deadlock between threads accessing and loading the C project descriptors. This and the rest of the build system needs a revisit.

Scalability issues with CDT indexer have been investigated. Some have been fixed but projects like Boost run out of memory at index time. Investigation will continue towards 8.5.

Largest change is spliting out CDT's native services, the Spawner, PTY handler, and Win32 registry access, has been split into a new feature and bundle. The CDT core fragments are now fragments of this new bundle, org.eclipse.cdt.core.native. Changes have been made to ensure the API is re-exported from their old home in cdt.core. This was done to support the TCF terminal view without dependencies on the entire CDT platform. This is a candidate for moving to a Commons project to be shared with other projects.
architecture.safe_value:
Continuing reports of deadlock between threads accessing and loading the C project descriptors. This and the rest of the build system needs a revisit.

Scalability issues with CDT indexer have been investigated. Some have been fixed but projects like Boost run out of memory at index time. Investigation will continue towards 8.5.

Largest change is spliting out CDT's native services, the Spawner, PTY handler, and Win32 registry access, has been split into a new feature and bundle. The CDT core fragments are now fragments of this new bundle, org.eclipse.cdt.core.native. Changes have been made to ensure the API is re-exported from their old home in cdt.core. This was done to support the TCF terminal view without dependencies on the entire CDT platform. This is a candidate for moving to a Commons project to be shared with other projects.

communities.safe_value: CDT user community is stable with a stable number of downloads for the Eclipse IDE for C/C++ Developers, >500,000 downloads of Kepler SR-1 for example. CDT committer community is stable. The number of active committers has dropped but those active remain very active. Contributions continue to roll in and are very visible thanks to Gerrit. More effort is needed to ensure patches get reviewed and submitted.
communities.value: CDT user community is stable with a stable number of downloads for the Eclipse IDE for C/C++ Developers, >500,000 downloads of Kepler SR-1 for example. CDT committer community is stable. The number of active committers has dropped but those active remain very active. Contributions continue to roll in and are very visible thanks to Gerrit. More effort is needed to ensure patches get reviewed and submitted.

noncode.value: User documentation has lagged behind again. We continue to ensure we're I18N compliant. Contributions continue to the CDT wiki.
noncode.safe_value: User documentation has lagged behind again. We continue to ensure we're I18N compliant. Contributions continue to the CDT wiki.

architecture.value:
The biggest Architectural issue we have today is the threading complexity around the indexer and it's various clients. We continue to see deadlocks at times (e.g. a recent bug where deleting a project while the reconciler is running). It would be great to single thread these features.

The CDT build system and it's project and configuration descriptors continue to be a mess. It's hard for contributors to understand this code. Rewriting this has been long on our wish list.

In this release we have provided extensibility to the index to support the overlay concepts from Qt including slots, signals, and properties which are capture by Qt's metaobject facility. This should help others who need to add concepts to the CDT index.
architecture.safe_value:
The biggest Architectural issue we have today is the threading complexity around the indexer and it's various clients. We continue to see deadlocks at times (e.g. a recent bug where deleting a project while the reconciler is running). It would be great to single thread these features.

The CDT build system and it's project and configuration descriptors continue to be a mess. It's hard for contributors to understand this code. Rewriting this has been long on our wish list.

In this release we have provided extensibility to the index to support the overlay concepts from Qt including slots, signals, and properties which are capture by Qt's metaobject facility. This should help others who need to add concepts to the CDT index.

description.value: Usability has been greatly improved around the paths and symbols area and scanner discovery settings. Work continues on supporting new C++ standards C++11 and C++14. We are working on C++11 and C++14 support available in gcc 4.8.
description.safe_value: Usability has been greatly improved around the paths and symbols area and scanner discovery settings. Work continues on supporting new C++ standards C++11 and C++14. We are working on C++11 and C++14 support available in gcc 4.8.

standards.value: Work continues on supporting new C++ standards C++11 and C++14. We are working on C++11 and C++14 support available in gcc 4.8.
standards.safe_value: Work continues on supporting new C++ standards C++11 and C++14. We are working on C++11 and C++14 support available in gcc 4.8.

usability.safe_value: Usability has been greatly improved around the paths and symbols area and scanner discovery settings. More work is necessary to the New Project wizard to make it easier for new users to get started.
usability.value: Usability has been greatly improved around the paths and symbols area and scanner discovery settings. More work is necessary to the New Project wizard to make it easier for new users to get started.

endoflife.value: The CDT CDI debug interface continues to be End of Lifed although still not removed.
endoflife.safe_value: The CDT CDI debug interface continues to be End of Lifed although still not removed.

usability.safe_value: No major changes there. We are still handcuffed by usability problems in the Platform, especially related to launching. Our new project wizard still requires a redo as well as it's fairly confusing selecting templates and toolchains. We're finding that commercial vendors that adopt the CDT usually provide their own implementations of these.
usability.value: No major changes there. We are still handcuffed by usability problems in the Platform, especially related to launching. Our new project wizard still requires a redo as well as it's fairly confusing selecting templates and toolchains. We're finding that commercial vendors that adopt the CDT usually provide their own implementations of these.

endoflife.safe_value: Nothing is end of lifed in this release.
endoflife.value: Nothing is end of lifed in this release.

description.safe_value:
The C/C++ Development Tooling (CDT) project provides plug-ins that support development of projects using the C and C++ programming languages and the common environments that support this language. C/C++ is used in embedded and mobile, desktop, and server applications, typically where application performance is a key requirement. The CDT provides a platform to support different build systems and debuggers, known as toolchains. Exemplary implementations of these extensions are provided for common environments with the gnu toolchain being the most prevalent.
 
Release 8.2 is delivered for the Eclipse Kepler simultaneous release. This is a minor release with no API changes allowed. There are a number of new features documented here and in the New and Noteworthy here: http://wiki.eclipse.org/CDT/User/NewIn82.
description.value:
The C/C++ Development Tooling (CDT) project provides plug-ins that support development of projects using the C and C++ programming languages and the common environments that support this language. C/C++ is used in embedded and mobile, desktop, and server applications, typically where application performance is a key requirement. The CDT provides a platform to support different build systems and debuggers, known as toolchains. Exemplary implementations of these extensions are provided for common environments with the gnu toolchain being the most prevalent.

 

Release 8.2 is delivered for the Eclipse Kepler simultaneous release. This is a minor release with no API changes allowed. There are a number of new features documented here and in the New and Noteworthy here: http://wiki.eclipse.org/CDT/User/NewIn82.

standards.value: We are adopting the new C++11 langauge standard. We are now looking at the next release of the standard currently code named C++14.
standards.safe_value: We are adopting the new C++11 langauge standard. We are now looking at the next release of the standard currently code named C++14.

architecture.safe_value: Build architecture continues to be a problem but we are making advances. The Scanner Discovery part of this is vastly improved in this release.
architecture.value: Build architecture continues to be a problem but we are making advances. The Scanner Discovery part of this is vastly improved in this release.

deliverables.value:
The CDT source code is contained in the org.eclipse.cdt.git repo and for this release is tagged CDT_8_2_0. Service releases are planned which will have the tags CDT_8_2_1 and CDT_8_2_2 for SR-1 and SR-2 respectively.

 

The CDT provides it's own update site with all features included. For 8.2, this site is located at http://download.eclipse.org/tools/cdt/releases/kepler.

 

The CDT also feeds the most commonly used features to the Kepler simultaneous release. Those are then used as part of the Ecilpse C/C++ IDE package.
deliverables.safe_value:
The CDT source code is contained in the org.eclipse.cdt.git repo and for this release is tagged CDT_8_2_0. Service releases are planned which will have the tags CDT_8_2_1 and CDT_8_2_2 for SR-1 and SR-2 respectively.
 
The CDT provides it's own update site with all features included. For 8.2, this site is located at http://download.eclipse.org/tools/cdt/releases/kepler.
 
The CDT also feeds the most commonly used features to the Kepler simultaneous release. Those are then used as part of the Ecilpse C/C++ IDE package.

themes.description: Work is ongoing to support the new C++11 language standard in the editor and parsers. That is near completion.
themes.name: Support C++11
Build Architecture
themes.description: Work is ongoing to improve the architecture of our build extension mechanism with special focus in this release on Scanner Discovery, the component that provides the parsers with knowledge of the build system for the code they are parsing.

Work continues to expand our support for common freely available toolchains. This includes support for the Qt build system and language extensions for Qt, as well as the new LLVM toolchain for Mac and other platforms.
themes.name: Expand toolchain support

themes.description: Work is ongoing to support new features of gdb as they are released.
themes.name: gdb Integration
MultiCore Visualization
themes.description: Work is ongoing to provide advances visualizations of multi-core systems under debug.

environment.value:
CDT targets all supported Eclipse enviornments. That is supported with support for the gnu toolchain which is available on all of those platforms. Additional focus is given to Windows, with Visual C++, and Mac, with LLVM, as well as other platforms that also support LLVM.

 

CDT requires JRE 1.6.
environment.safe_value:
CDT targets all supported Eclipse enviornments. That is supported with support for the gnu toolchain which is available on all of those platforms. Additional focus is given to Windows, with Visual C++, and Mac, with LLVM, as well as other platforms that also support LLVM.
 
CDT requires JRE 1.6.

i18n.safe_value: Localization of Strings and icons is a requirement of the CDT. All effort is put forward to meet that requirement. No testing is made public, however, is done to ensure that's true. It is believe that a number of adopters do partake in that testing on their own as we have had bugs reporting issues.
i18n.value: Localization of Strings and icons is a requirement of the CDT. All effort is put forward to meet that requirement. No testing is made public, however, is done to ensure that's true. It is believe that a number of adopters do partake in that testing on their own as we have had bugs reporting issues.

communities.value:
User community is very high with almost 2 million downloads of the Eclipse C++ IDE package last 12 months.

 

Contributions continue at a good pace and are captured in Gerrit. A couple of individuals have really stepped up to help especially with C++11 support and docs. Bugzilla traffic is high both in bugs raised and communication with the committers.

 

We have 16 active committers with three close to inactive. And of course we all vary with amount activity as most committers are only part time working on CDT directly.

 

We continue to hold our monthly conference call. Details are here: http://wiki.eclipse.org/CDT/calls.

 

Mark Khouzam and Doug Schaefer presented an update on the CDT at EclipseCon 2013 in Boston. We also held a CDT summit there that was attended by 30 people, a pretty good number.

noncode.value: Docs have received an number of contributions this release. Not much else has been updated.
noncode.safe_value: Docs have received an number of contributions this release. Not much else has been updated.

compatibility.safe_value: API compatability is maintained with previous 8.x CDT releases. CDT 8.2 will run against 3.8 and newer Eclipse Platform releases.
